software training admin the whole nine yards what that should be telling people

of them are really taking information security as seriously as we'd like to think that they would and one of the key

accountability for not investing money in information security and because
shadowed with the economic Times that we've faced in the past two two and a half years what you also see is that
unless you can really clearly Define a return on investment people are pushing

security something happens and I have a story on the Wall Street Journal on the front page of the Wall Street Journal

saying what do you think of these three managed security service providers what kind of people do they hire so here's

would think or consider this to our organization is on a complete Outsourcing Trend especially from the

evaluating managed security service providers the other challenge to add to
Le Point is is that we kind of talk our own language you know we have cool things like firewalls and intrusion
detection and Port scanners and and mappers and things like that and we tend to be insular with our communication and
the problem is the board the CFO the CEO they don't understand that language what
they know is the security guy wants more money for another widget and I gave him money last year for a bunch of widgets
and he told me that would make us secure now he's coming back again this year and he wants more widgets cuz not really as
secure as we thought we were going to be so they don't necessarily understand the language that we're we're talking and so
where I've seen organizations be very successful and and who by the way who struggles to get funding for security
projects I mean right it's a big problem and and where I've seen organizations be
successful and I'm working with one right now that that is going to be very successful is they've learned to get
away from talking about widgets and they've started to talk about not necessarily return on investment which
is a good thing if you can figure it out I still haven't figured out how that works but if you can start to tie what
you're doing to the organization's business objectives what are the five things my company wants to accomplish
this year and then in order to do that what do we need from a security perspective to make that happen and and
one area where PWC has been very successful is selling identity Management Solutions to some of our
larger you know Fortune 10 type of clients and we never go in and talk about firewall walls and ldaps and
directory structures there's never a the conversation goes like this you want an Employee Self-Service portal and you
think that's going to save you $10 million a year if your employees can you know get their payroll their pay stub online and change their benefits and if
they have a self-service portal well in order to do that you need security to make sure that employee a can't see
employees and B's you know information or vice versa and that's pretty much where the conversation stops because we
look we can do that for you we know how to build that and this is what it's going to cost you but you know it's going to cost you $2 million but you're
going to save $10 million over the next two years and that's the end of the conversation and we're done and we move
on and we can do the work because we've tied it to a business objective having an Employee Self-Service portal we've
tied it to how much money they're going to save and we've gotten out of the realm of widgets we're not talking about
